content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

1. In Julia, you can write a function `clean_column` to clean a column name by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore using the following code snippet:
```julia
# Define the function `clean_column` to clean a column name.
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the column name.
    col = lowercase(col)

    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces from the column name.
    col = strip(col)

    # Replace spaces and hyphens with an underscore in the column name.
    col = replace(col, " " => "_")
    col = replace(col, "-" => "_")

    return col
end
```
2. To use this function `clean_column` on a given column `col`, you can simply pass it as an argument to the function:
```julia
# Define the original column name.
col = "My Column"

# Call the clean_column function to clean the column name.
col_cleaned = clean_column(col)

println("Cleaned column name: ", col_cleaned)
```
Output:
```
Cleaned column name:  my_column
```
This code snippet will first lowercase, strip any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replace any spaces and hyphens with an underscore in the given column name `col`. The cleaned column name is then returned by the function.
